snippet: While ordinary tourism remains banned by law, new rules put in place by President Obama will make it easier for Americans to visit Cuba than it has been for most of the last 50 years.
abstract: Obama administration will ease restrictions to make travel between United States and Cuba easier; ordinary tourism remains banned by law, but as airlines seek approval to begin regular service between countries, Americans only have to indicate that they have legitimate reason for their travel.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
byline.contributor: Peter Baker reported from Washington, and Randal C. Archibold from Havana. Frances Robles contributed reporting from Miami, and Victoria Burnett from Mexico City.

lead_paragraph: While ordinary tourism remains banned by law, new rules put in place by President Obama will make it easier for Americans to visit Cuba than it has been for most of the last 50 years.

headline.main: Starting Friday, U.S. Will Ease Restrictions on Travel to Cuba
headline.print_headline: U.S. to Relax Limits on Cuba Travel, Opening Door to Commercial Flights
